record.author: Claire MOYSE-FAURIE & Marie-Adèle NECHERÖ-JOREDIE
record.notes:
The data used here are coming from a dictionnary made by Claire MOYSE-FAURIE & Marie-Adèle NECHERÖ-JOREDIE in 1989. It is presented in the book Dictionnaire Xârâcùù-Français (Nouvelle-Calédonie), Nouméa : Les Editions Populaires, 288 pp. It provides a phonological, greographical, and sociolinguistical introduction to the Xârâcùù, language spoken in the Kouaoua-Canala-Thio areas (located on the east cost of the New Caledonia Main Land ('Grande-Terre'). This book, intended to speakers usage, provides two lexicons, one in xârâcùù-french, and one in french-xârâcùù.
Methodology used here to enter the lexical data : - The synonymy has been reduced by going through both lexicons. - When two words in Xârâcùù are presented with a slash (for instance "xãⁿdɨ/xãⁿdɤ", it means that those words are two morphological forms of the same word (generally related to geographical distribution of this word). - When both simple words and compound words are possible in Xârâcùù to translate a word in the list, we have opted for the simple words. - When a word is not phonologically autonomous (i.e being a prefix or a suffix), a dash has been put after the word (prefix) or before the word (suffix). - When a word in the list can not be translated by a single general item in xârâcùù, some semantic specifications for each one of them have been provided in the 'author annotation' column.
record.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Central-Eastern Oceanic, Remote Oceanic, New Caledonian, Southern, South, Xaracuu-Xaragure

record.annotation: Refers to the dust like 'ashes' or 'coming from wood' and 'falling down'
Refers to the dust 'in the air'
'to spit, to reject something like food'
'to do something that has death as a consequence'
In two words, means 'to inflate something by blowing on it', there is no ather term to refere as 'to swell'
Can be used as a verb with a similar meaning
Used for people and things that are big, or for quantities that are big
Used as a general term for short without any distinction between height and length features of objects
The distinction between those three words seems to be related to syntactic purposes
The distinction between those two words seems to be related to syntactic purposes as well
Something new that comes from the outside word not endemic ('a stranger' for instance)
(1) Something new, mostly vegetables, like a new tree, a young coconut, etc
Tends to mean 'for the first time'
Used for instance in sentences like 'he is angry at his wife'
Prepositions used for event without motion (for instance 'he is at the beach')
Prepositions used for event without motion (for instance 'he is at the beach')
Used for more respectful way of adressing
Appears to be used for anaphoric purposes
Used before a noun (i.e is the more general word for 'other')
Provides a negative polarity to a sentence
